message.content: We refer to information from UpToDate for help. The symptoms of joint pain, chronic headache, and weight loss suggest a possible diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA). The asymmetrical pulse in the upper extremities also indicates a possible occlusion of the subclavian artery. The elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate further support the suspicion of GCA. The best next step in management is to start prednisone, a corticosteroid, at a high dose of 40-60 mg per day, as this is the standard treatment for GCA. Anti-dsDNA level is not relevant to the diagnosis of GCA. Methotrexate is used for management of rheumatoid arthritis, which has a different clinical presentation than GCA. Temporal artery biopsy is a confirmatory test for GCA, but treatment with corticosteroids should be initiated before the biopsy is performed to avoid delay in treatment.
